answers.answer: Sorry this got posted on wrong one!  Suppose to be the ask a doctor...unless someone out there is neuro!! LOL

question: I am a 55 year old female diagnosed with fibromyalgia in 2000.  I have tried different meds for this but have the chemical sensitivity that sometimes goes along with fibro.  I currently am taking only Synthroid for hypothyroid and multivitamin, CoQ10, 5HTP, and niacin, and occasion Lorcet Plus for pain.  Other than the fibro, I am in good health.  No migraines, no high blood pressure, no diabetes, etc.My question is: I have had two very severe episodes of pain in past month (about 3 weeks apart)...one of which was so severe I couldn't get out of bed without assistance.  Both only last a day or so...had tingly "gone to sleep" feeling in legs after each episode.  My family doc decided to do an MRI after I told him about having MRI about 15 years ago which showed "suspicious spots" that neuro said were indicative of MS.  Spinal fluid exam however did not.  He (the neuro) told me that he couldn't say I didn't or wouldn't have it "down the road" b/c of these spots, but couldn't say I did right then b/c of the spinal fluid.Anyway, the latest MRI showed "several areas of hyperintensity on T2 weighed images in the periventricular white matter and centrum semivale.  These are bilateral and fairly symmetric.  These are however nonspecific.  This could be microvascular change from aretiosclerosis.  They also have been described in patients with history of migraine headaches and vasculitits.  Considering her age, I doubt demyelinating process such as MS.  There are no highly specific lesions for this process. These do not enhance postcontrast."I have never had migraines or the vasculitis...so if the radiologist had know of previous MRI results(it was done at another hospital, so no comparison), do you think she would have come to same conclusion?  And if this is negative, what type of doctor should I see for follow-up for the two episodes?Many thanks!
title: Hyperintensity area on T2 weighed images
